Bug.Summery: Add an 'Open Manifest' to projects to open the manifest editor

Lines.Line: 1. it does not seem to recognize fragment.xml
2. the package org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.editor would make a better home for the action
3. the patch did not apply cleanly due to changes in PDEUIMessage that must have occurred in the meantime.

Bug.WithStack:
I find it annoying that I have to drill down into a project or the META-INF directory to open up the manifest editor, especially when there's an Update Classpath and Migrate to 3.0 in the menu.
I'd really like an Open Manifest editor link on the Project. Fortunately, I know you guys are really busy with 3.2M5 on the corner, so I saved you the bother and wrote it for you :-)
I'll attach a patch in a sec (just got to sync to a Head to make sure it still works) and would appreciate a review of the code if possible. Some of the message handling isn't true NLS-worthy yet, for example, and I'm not sure if there's a better way of referring to the manifest than META-INF/MANIFEST.MF ...
Anyway, I've found this really useful already and I hope that other PDE users will too.
(attachment to follow) Created attachment 37155 Adds OpenManifest to a plugin project
Adds an Open Manifest to a plugin project. This was created from HEAD so should be relatively up-to-date. I've tested it against 3.2M5 to check the functionality, but had problems with running from HEAD, so I'm not sure if I've merged the changes across well or whether there's a problem with the current version. However, I'm not going to get any more done tonight so thought it would be useful showing the first draft of the code in case anyone's got time to review it and make comments. How does one go about writing a test for this? Thanks Alex. It's a useful function
I took a quick look. In addition to the TODOs you had, 1. it does not seem to recognize fragment.xml 2. the package org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.editor would make a better home for the action 3. the patch did not apply cleanly due to changes in PDEUIMessage that must have occurred in the meantime.
We would like to stabilize the translatable strings by M6, so that the translators can get to work. It would therefore be good if you revise the patch before noon EST. Otherwise, I'm not sure it will go in for 3.2
No, at present, it doesn't recognize fragment.xml, just plugin.xml and MANIFEST.MF. Shouldn't be too hard to put in a check for those though.
The other package sounds like a reasonable place for it.
I created the changes to PDEUIMessages last night, so I'm wondering what would have happened in the meantime? There were only 3 new entries anyway:
+ public static String OpenManifestsAction_cannotFind; + + public static String OpenManifestsAction_cannotOpen; + + public static String OpenManifestsAction_title;
Unfortunately, I don't have the ability to do work on this during office hours, so the earliest I could hit the patch again is around 20:00 GMT+1, which is after 12:00 EST, unless I can get it done before I go into work. Would it be possible to apply the changes and then fix the fragment.xml loading code later? Created attachment 37180 OpenManifest patch with new action location
I've moved the action to the new package and updated the plugin.xml accordingly. I'm not sure why the plugin.xml has so many changes; I updated it to HEAD and so there may have been some formatting done (they look mostly like whitespace changes). Not implemented fragment.xml yet; will do it this evening. patch applied with minor changes. thanks. Cool. I actually extended the implementation to check for feature.xml, plugin.xml and fragment.xml if you wanted that :-)
I also discovered that I had to put two extensions in the plugin.xml; one for the filter type nature=org.eclipse.pde.PluginNature and one for nature=org.eclipse.pde.FeatureNature (otherwise the feature.xml didn't work). I'd have liked to have one point for both, but it didn't seem to have the ability for an 'or' filter. (The other approach would have been to change the WorkbenchProject IActionFilter to understand a comma-separated list of project natures instead of just one; but that would have required more changes.)
<objectContribution objectClass="org.eclipse.core.resources.IProject" adaptable="true" id="org.eclipse.pde.ui.pluginProjectToolSet"> <menu label="%org.eclipse.pde.ui.tools" id="org.eclipse.pde.ui.project.tools"> <separator name="group0"> </separator> </menu> <filter name="projectNature" value="org.eclipse.pde.FeatureNature"> </filter> <action label="%OpenManifest.label" class="org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.editor.OpenManifestAction" menubarPath="org.eclipse.pde.ui.project.tools/group0" enablesFor="+" id="org.eclipse.pde.ui.OpenManifest"> </action> </objectContribution>
The downside of this is if you have a selection with both features and plugins, it doesn't show the action since it's not common to all selected types.
I also changed OpenManifestAction to have fragment/features:
|| WorkspaceModelManager.hasFeatureManifest(project) || WorkspaceModelManager.hasFragmentManifest(project))) and I thought this was neater on reflection: if (WorkspaceModelManager.hasBundleManifest(project)) file = project.getFile("META-INF/MANIFEST.MF"); else if (WorkspaceModelManager.hasPluginManifest(project)) file = project.getFile("plugin.xml"); else if (WorkspaceModelManager.hasFeatureManifest(project)) file = project.getFile("feature.xml"); else if (WorkspaceModelManager.hasFragmentManifest(project)) file = project.getFile("fragment.xml");
I also caught the error when it couldn't find any manifests after my earlier patch :-)
BTW the resources are a bit odd; there's OpenManifestsAction_... and OpenManifestAction_... -- might be good to get rid of my plural name and put them all together in the same place.
Thanks for getting it in so quickly!
Alex.

Bug.Summery: DeleteAction.createCommand(Collection) ends up calling BasicEObjectImpl.eDynamicGet(EStructuralFeature, boolean) with an invalid feature

Lines.Line: 1- my tree viewer handled SelectionEvent by firing SelectionChangedEvent.
2- that event is handled by an org.eclipse.emf.edit.ui.action.DeleteAction instance.
4- the createCommand method calls RemoveCommand.create(domain, selection)

5- once inside AdapterFactoryEditingDomain.createCommand(Class, CommandParameter) we reach line 445 because the commandParameter has no owner specified and BananaItemProvider overrides ItemProviderAdapter.getParent(Object) to return the banana's bananaCrate. Just in case, this is line 445 for me: "removeCommand.append(createCommand(RemoveCommand.class, new CommandParameter(parent, null, siblings)));".
6- now that createCommand has been called with an 'owner' in the commandParameter we reach line 391 ("editingDomainItemProvider.createCommand(owner, this, commandClass, commandParameter)")

7- inside ItemProviderAdapter.createCommand, since we are creating a RemoveCommand and 'commandParameter.getEStructuralFeature()' is null, we reach line 787 ("factorRemoveCommand(domain, commandParameter)")

8- inside ItemProviderAdapter.factorRemoveCommand is where I kind of loose track of what's going on. It seems to be trying to find from which feature should Banana1 be removed (should be 'bananas'). What happens is that we reach line 317 and "Banana1.eGet(EStructuralFeature eFeature, boolean resolve)" is called with the "apples" feature. Then "eDynamicGet(eFeature, resolve)" is called, which throws an IllegalArgumentException.

Bug.WithStack:
Let's say I have a model with three objects: Crate, Apple and Banana. Crate has two collection features, one for Apple and Banana. Apple and Banana, thought they always "belong" to Crate, they are not contained in Crate in the EMF sense. (This is because they need to be persisted in different Resources)
The two Crate EList features are "apples" and "bananas". The opposite of "apples" in Apple is "appleCrate" and the opposite of "bananas" in Banana is "bananaCrate".
Anyway, let's say I have a tree view of my model with the following instances: Crate1 ...Apple1 ...Apple2 ...Apple3 ...Apple4 ...Apple5 ...Banana1 (the apples & the banana are "inside" Create1)
The following happens when I click on Banana1:
1- my tree viewer handled SelectionEvent by firing SelectionChangedEvent.
2- that event is handled by an org.eclipse.emf.edit.ui.action.DeleteAction instance.
3- the DeleteAction calls 'createCommand(Collection selection)'
4- the createCommand method calls RemoveCommand.create(domain, selection)
5- once inside AdapterFactoryEditingDomain.createCommand(Class, CommandParameter) we reach line 445 because the commandParameter has no owner specified and BananaItemProvider overrides ItemProviderAdapter.getParent(Object) to return the banana's bananaCrate. Just in case, this is line 445 for me: "removeCommand.append(createCommand(RemoveCommand.class, new CommandParameter(parent, null, siblings)));".
6- now that createCommand has been called with an 'owner' in the commandParameter we reach line 391 ("editingDomainItemProvider.createCommand(owner, this, commandClass, commandParameter)")
7- inside ItemProviderAdapter.createCommand, since we are creating a RemoveCommand and 'commandParameter.getEStructuralFeature()' is null, we reach line 787 ("factorRemoveCommand(domain, commandParameter)")
8- inside ItemProviderAdapter.factorRemoveCommand is where I kind of loose track of what's going on. It seems to be trying to find from which feature should Banana1 be removed (should be 'bananas'). What happens is that we reach line 317 and "Banana1.eGet(EStructuralFeature eFeature, boolean resolve)" is called with the "apples" feature. Then "eDynamicGet(eFeature, resolve)" is called, which throws an IllegalArgumentException.
Note: there must be more than four Apples in Crate1, otherwise EcoreEList.contains(Object) will not reach line 317 ("((EObject)object).eGet(getInverseEReference())").
This is the top part of the stack trace:
EObjectWithInverseResolvingEList(EcoreEList).contains(Object) line: 317 CrateItemProvider(ItemProviderAdapter).factorRemoveCommand(EditingDomain, CommandParameter) line: 1071 CrateItemProvider(ItemProviderAdapter).createCommand(Object, EditingDomain, Class, CommandParameter) line: 787 AdapterFactoryEditingDomain.createCommand(Class, CommandParameter) line: 391 AdapterFactoryEditingDomain.createCommand(Class, CommandParameter) line: 445 RemoveCommand.create(EditingDomain, Object, Object, Collection) line: 98 RemoveCommand.create(EditingDomain, Collection) line: 90 DeleteDomainObjectAction(DeleteAction).createCommand(Collection) line: 49 ...
Thank you in advance for any help you can provide. Another thing: if the Banana class had had many features, I wouldn't have noticed this behaviour because the ID of the "apples" feature would have matched the ID of one of Banana's features. Alejandro,
I'm going to assume this is a duplicate of 112330 unless you provide a test case that demonstrates it's not a duplicate.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 112330 ***

Bug.Summery: [Help] Commands in help docs should only apply to workbench mode

Stacktrace.Reason: Failed to execute runnable (java.lang.IllegalStateException: Workbench has not been created yet.)

Cause.Reason: Workbench has not been created yet.

Lines.Line: 1) In infocenter mode the proper dialog was already appearing as Konrad pointed out.
2) Curtis, you might want to tweak the error message text if you can think of something better.

3) This patch fixes command links, which all filter through the same ILiveHelpAction implementation class (ExecuteCommandAction). But it doesn't fix the similar problem with the lone active help link in the PDE developer guide, or any other active links.

One more thing about note (3) in the previous comment. The ILiveHelpAction run() is called from BaseHelpSystem.runLiveHelp() which is in org.eclipse.help.base. You couldn't open a dialog from there (right?) so I think instrumenting each ILiveHelpAction, or introducing some abstract base class (AbstractLiveHelpAction) with the checks is how this has to be handled.

You should see a dialog that says, "you need to run help locally....". We should do the same for command links.
I'll look into this.... Sounds good to me. Well I thought this would be easy, but I'm actually stuck on two fronts.
First, I don't know how to run help as infocenter/standalone so I basically don't know how to reproduce the problem and test a fix (if I had one).
Second, I'm surprised and can't explain why these command links don't exhibit the same behavior as the active help example I linked above. Both active help and command links use javascript. The active help calls javascript:liveAction(...) and the command links call javascript:executeCommand(...). Both of those functions are defined in livehelp.js and if you look at the definition of executeCommand you see it just calls liveAction, so in both cases the code flows through very similar paths. So basically I can't see why the error dialog appears in the active help case but not in the command link case. I'm also not sure who creates that error dialog for the active help case. I think if we I could find where the error dialog is created it would help.
Dejan and/or Curtis, do you have any insight on either of these questions? It is puzzling indeed.
Konrad, we have a live help action that is not supposed to work outside of the WORKBENCH mode (as any other live help action). When we try the sample live action specified above from the info center, the warning dialog opens up. However, when we follow our own live help action, we don't get the dialog. Why is that? To run infocenter:
http://help.eclipse.org/help31/topic/org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/reference/misc/help_infocenter.html
To run standalone:
http://help.eclipse.org/help31/topic/org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/reference/misc/help_standalone.html
First, I see your stack if from standalone help scenario and you compare the behavior to the infocenter. The infocenter and standalone scenarios are not the same. Live help does not apply to infocenter, due to executing on the server, multi user, and security reasons. However it is perfectly valid to execute live help actions in standalone help. The action does not need need to require IDE or workbench or SWT, it may perform project creation, installation, execute external scripts, or other non UI, or non IDE tasks.
The text from the error dialog that appears in the infocter scenario is comiing from proprties, so simple text search of the webapp will reveal the properties file and the key used. Search for the key will return place with the logic for displaying the dialog: livehelp_js.jsp: if(data.getMode() == RequestData.MODE_INFOCENTER){ alert("<%=UrlUtil.JavaScriptEncode(ServletResources.getString("noLiveHelpInInfocenter", request))%>"); return; }else if(!prefs.isActiveHelp()){ alert("<%=UrlUtil.JavaScriptEncode(ServletResources.getString("noLiveHelp", request))%>");
Since some people need to run livehelp in standalone, but most would rather disable them, notice there is a preference that that can be set when launching standalone and live help will not work.
In particular case of this bug, I think no changes are needed to the live help framework. The action implementation should check its prerequisites, like if the workbench exists if it needs it. If the workbench is not up, the action can even display an SWT dialog (if SWT exists), and I see from the stack the SWT loop is well running. Thanks, Konrad. I missed the standalone/infocenter mismatch. Created attachment 37580 opens error dialog when command link executed in standalone help mode
Here is a patch that causes an error dialog to open when command links are executed in standalone mode.
Notes: 1) In infocenter mode the proper dialog was already appearing as Konrad pointed out.
2) Curtis, you might want to tweak the error message text if you can think of something better.
3) This patch fixes command links, which all filter through the same ILiveHelpAction implementation class (ExecuteCommandAction). But it doesn't fix the similar problem with the lone active help link in the PDE developer guide, or any other active links. One more thing about note (3) in the previous comment. The ILiveHelpAction run() is called from BaseHelpSystem.runLiveHelp() which is in org.eclipse.help.base. You couldn't open a dialog from there (right?) so I think instrumenting each ILiveHelpAction, or introducing some abstract base class (AbstractLiveHelpAction) with the checks is how this has to be handled.
Applied.

Bug.Summery: [Help] Keyword index doesn't automatically scroll on typing (Mac)
Bug.WithStack:
I20060328-0010
On the mac, if you open the help window and switch to the index view (you need to have index content present), it won't scroll and highlight keywords as you type them. This works in the index view. Kiryl, any ideas why it might not work on Safari? We're using MacOSX 10.4, Safari 2.0.3. I believe that the problem is somewhere in JavaScript code.
Are there any JavaScript problems reporter in Safari (like JavaScript console in Mozilla or script debugging in IE)? It would be good to see if any error occurs during typing of a keyword. Created attachment 37214 javascript console
Indeed I see errors in the javascript console.. anything look familiar? Created attachment 37316 fix candidate
Possibly the problem in window.getSelection(), which does not returns Selection object if nothing selected in the window. I have found some discussions about this in the Internet. Hope the proposed patch will fix the problem. Thanks Kiryl. M6 is shutting down so will apply for RC1. Applied.

Bug.Summery: Ease Report Migration
Bug.WithStack: To encourage the use of BIRT by the development community, it must be easy for developers to migrate BIRT reports across environments such as from development to testing to production. To support this goal, BIRT 2.1 should provide capabilities in the Eclipse environment that make it easy for the developer to deploy the BIRT reports in their application using visual tools. This includes packaging up reports and all their dependent components such as libraries, scripted data source (Java class files), war files for the BIRT runtime, images, and other related artifacts.
Bug.WithOutStack: To encourage the use of BIRT by the development community, it must be easy for developers to migrate BIRT reports across environments such as from development to testing to production. To support this goal, BIRT 2.1 should provide capabilities in the Eclipse environment that make it easy for the developer to deploy the BIRT reports in their application using visual tools. This includes packaging up reports and all their dependent components such as libraries, scripted data source (Java class files), war files for the BIRT runtime, images, and other related artifacts.

Bug.Summery: [dnd] Drag and drop file from navigator to editor inserts relative file path
Bug.WithStack:
It'd be nice if when you drag and drop a file from the package explorer to the editor, the text inserted is the path of that file, relative to the file in the editor you just dropped it to.
For example: WebContent -myJSP.jsp -myFolder --myFile.jsp
If I drag and drop myFile.jsp onto myJSP.jsp, I would like "myFolder/myFile.jsp" to be inserted.
Currently, the file path relative to the project root is inserted instead: "WebContent/myFolder/myFile.jsp" and, ... ideally ... its would actually insert an href= too, right, if in the right context?
reassigning to inbox Good idea. But I would also think there should be a preference, some may want root relative links while others want document relative links.

Bug.Summery: Doc says CVS doesn't implement file modification validator
Bug.WithStack:
Doc file: team_provider_repository.htm
Contains this line:
"Since CVS uses an optimistic versioning scheme, it does not implement this hook."
This isn't quite true. CVS does implement the file modification hook (for watch/edit mode). Fixed. Moving to new M1 milestone
